Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: REVSYS: Phylogenetic and revisionary systematics of a diverse clade of avian schistosomes (Platyhelminthes: Schistosomatidae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Schistosomes are blood fluke parasites that are significant pathogens of humans as well as domestic and wild vertebrate hosts. The schistosomes that occur in birds represent over 65% of known schistosome species diversity, yet they remain understudied. Bird schistosomes are also responsible for swimmer's itch in humans. In this project, schistosome diversity will be studied by targeted collecting of under sampled and high diversity areas. Identifications will be done using modern approaches to morphological and genetic characterization. The goal is to develop an evolutionary tree of schistosome species, describe the many new species discovered, and produce a monographic treatment for schistosomes. In addition, the resulting evolutionary tree will be used to study the evolution of traits within this clade, with broad implications for evolution within the family Schistosomatidae. This research will greatly increase our understanding of a globally distributed group of parasites and provide the tools necessary for species identification.

The project involves faculty from two EPSCoR states and fosters broad international collaboration in Argentina, France, Kenya, and China. The study will improve and build on a natural history museum collection of parasites that is globally accessible. Finally undergraduates and graduate students will be involved with and trained in all aspects of the project. Information generated by this project will be made available to scientists and the medical community, with outreach through K-12 education, and to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this research was to collect, catalogue, identify, (re)describe parasites from a family of trematodes, Schistosomatidae.  We had already as well as traveled and collected worms in 15 countries, found 55 species (15 new species) that includes 25 genera (13 new) with detailed natural histories (with 11 published papers thus far). We have reconstructed the most up to date phylogenetic history of all of these species, and are still working on analyzing the genomic data before publication. This will be one of the first phylogenies to include most of the know species diversity. Based on our results and survey of avian schistosomes, there are still hosts and ecologies and geographic areas where we can predict several new species.The Museum of Southwestern Biology, Division of Parasites, now holds the largest, publicly available catalogued collection of the Schistosomatidae. It is searchable by anyone around the world via the ARCTOS Database.

The mechanisms that maintain the relationships among hosts and their parasites are proposed to be several, (e.g. coexisting parasites, immune function, evolutionary history) and in this work, that is no less true. For example, for some species, it was a long history with a particular host that defined their relationship and in another species, it looked like history, but turned out to be the very specific ecology of both the duck and the snail host. If the habitat changed and the two host species were no longer together more often than not, so to would the host distribution/use of the schistosome change. Even within a closely related group of confamilial avian schistosomes in birds, the mechanisms responsible for observed host use and distributions were not uniform nor predictable, at least not now. For example, for two species of schistosomes, each using a migratory bird host AND each bird migrating to areas north and south with suitable aquatic snail hosts, one species of schistosome was widespread, but the other one was not. This is a topic worth in depth research for these particular species of schistosomes to test the mechanisms responsible for observed patterns uncovered as a result of this work. The results of this research has put us in a position where we can start asking larger questions about host use, immunology, biogeography, host specificity etc to look at how a family of worms (in this case Schistosomatidae) has diversified and maintained trajectory over time and space. In the field of Parasitology within Biology, the breadth of taxonomic, geographic and host species sampling within this family of trematodes allow us to make broad statements about the evolutionary and ecological relationships of these host-parasite interactions and relating that back to core seminal papers in parasitology about both the specificity and plasticity of these symbiotic relationships. By the time we have finished collecting the genomic data for the family tree, we will have reconstructed a model system that can be used in parasite evolution and ecology, ecosystem dynamics, immunobiology and co-evolution, for example.

This project directly trained 2 Ph.D. graduate students and 5 undergraduate students. Additionally, because of the nature of the grant, we develop a summer STEM course where students collected parasites and hosts in the field, then brought them back to the museum for identification and curation. They also had the opportunity to think about ecosystems in context of the samples they collected. Albuquerque has a Naturalist Series and Master Naturalist programs in their parks where we lectured and gave demonstrations about parasites and their hosts. Parasites are certainly something no one is familiar with. Our biggest impact so far is having a reasonably complete dataset that is available for training community groups through talks, exhibits, and classroom. We already have a test exhibit that we take to kids and have them reconstruct an ecosystem, starting with the parasites and using the results of this work to show how from there they evolve over time and space. It is a way to teach them about parasites, by asking them to construct parasite natural history based on what they know already - plants, water, birds, mice, arthropods and how that makes up healthy ecosystems or not.
